habitat_description:
The first report of the Inyo Mountains salamander dates from 1973 from two desert springs, French Spring and Long John Canyon on the western slopes of the Inyo Mountains in the Mojave in northern California (Marlow et al. 1979). Following surveys have resulted in the extension of the distribution to more localities within the Inyo Mountains to include the eastern slopes (Giuliani 1990; Papenfuss and Macey 1986; Jennings and Hayes 1994). The northern limits of its distribution is in the Waucoba Canyon at 2285 meters in an east slope and Barrel Spring, a west slope at 1950 meters; the southernmost sites include a west slope in Long John Canyon at 1695 to 1830 meters and Hunter Canyon, an east slope at 490 to 915 meters. The overall elevation range at which populations occur is from 490 in Hunter Canyon to 2590 meters in upper Lead Canyon (Giuliani 1977; Papenfuss 1986). Stebbins (2003) provides an elevational range of 550-2620 meters.
Populations occur in habitat surrounded by large areas desert or semi-desert terrain; this is one of the two species known to occur in desert ecosystems (Lannoo 2005). Thus, the species is restrictedly found in perennial springs and seepages (Green et al. 2013).
Eggs are presumably deposited in moist crevices within the outcrops of the Inyo Mountains; adults and juveniles have been reported under rocks on moist substrates. Populations occur over east-west oriented canyons that dissect both north-south slopes of the Inyo Mountains. Habitat encountered in this region includes northern Mojave Desert with vegetation associations of creosote bush scrub, and lower elevations that grade into Great Basin communities like sagebrush steppe and pinyon juniper woodland at higher elevations (Marlow et al. 1979; Lannoo 2005). Habitat also includes perennial springs and seepages and the associated riparian vegetation usually found within discrete sections of steep canyons. Plants of these areas include willow, wild rose, and coyote brush that grow in dense thickets blocking sunlight from reaching ground level. It has been reported that this species of salamanders are restricted to these habitats where cliffs of solid rock, or talus contact surface flow (Giuliani 1977; Macey and Papenfuss 1991). 
Individuals have been reported resting on wet substrates, under rocks, or sometimes under woody debris, within clumps of moist ferns growing in waterfall splash zones (Giuliani 1977; Papenfuss and Macey 1986). During unfavorable conditions, refugia is offered by the adjacent granitic or limestone outcrops. At least at higher elevations, salamanders are not restricted to riparian or canyon bottom habitats, but are also encountered within pinyon-juniper woodlands.
